Trust Patient property transfer / disclaimer form ........................................................... 8
Managing Patient Valuables & Personal Property ........................................................ 9
Temporary custody of valuables, monies and cash .................................................... 12
Introduction

The Trust has a responsibility to provide safe custody for money and other personal property (hereafter referred to as "property") handed in by patients, in the possession of unconscious or confused patients, or found in the possession of patients dying in hospital or dead on arrival (Mental Capacity Act 2005)

It should be emphasised that Trust staff are not responsible for visitors' property, and to make this absolutely clear, disclaimer notices MUST be prominently displayed in each ward and department area.

Patients should be verbally advised that the Trust will not accept responsibility or liability for patients' property brought into Health Service premises, unless it is handed in for safe custody and a copy of an official patients' property record is obtained as a receipt. Patient property not placed in safe custody remains the responsibility of the patient who has capacity. Staff should ensure that all patients who have capacity sign a Trust patient property transfer / disclaimer form (343a) and be encouraged to send valuables home.

The policy will provide a framework that ensures that patients and service users are protected so as staff are not able to benefit financially or inappropriately gain from them use their property for personal use, borrow money from them or sell or dispose of property for their own gain.
It operates within the Trust's Standing Financial Instructions and detailed financial procedures.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide the safe custody of inpatient valuables and personal property handed to the Trust by patients or relatives.
Ensure that the inpatient's property is secured appropriately when patients are unable to care for their own property.
Provide a framework for the return of property – including valuable property- to patients, Next of Kin and staff acting on behalf of a current inpatient.

To define to staff, patients and visitors their responsibilities for their own belongings whilst on Trust property. In the case of a patient who is a child or young person under the age of 16 years, the responsibility for their belongings will be that of their parent or guardian.
This policy will not apply to outpatients.
Definitions

table_items.text: This term includes money and any other personal property belonging to the patient and brought into hospital as an inpatient.
The term valuables include any item of value (including, but not limited, to monetary value,.e.g. cash, credit/ debit cards, portable electronic devices and jewellery.
Property taken into Trust care for safekeeping, either following an explicit agreement with the patient or because the patient is incapacitated or otherwise unable to look after it.
This is the property that patients' retain with them and take

This is not a definitive list, but the most likely items that would be covered by this policy are: Money Jewellery Watches Bank Cards Cheque books Savings books Phones, laptops or tablets Terms such as ‘gold' and ‘silver must not be used when describing items of jewellery. Descriptions such as ‘yellow metal' or ‘white metal' must be used instead. Stones in rings or other jewellery must not be described as ‘diamond', ‘ruby' etc., but the term ‘white stone', ‘red stone' must be used instead

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the provision of a safe and secure environment for patients and their property whilst on Trust premises. The Chief Executive is responsible for ensuring patients or their guardians, as appropriate, are informed before, or at the time of admission that the Trust will not accept responsibility or liability for patients' property brought onto its premises, unless it is handed in for safe custody and a copy of an official patients' property record obtained as a receipt (Form 343a) Appendix one. This information will be  communicated by: Notices and information booklets, hospital admission and property records. The oral advice given by administrative and nursing staff responsible for admissions and inter ward transfers within the hospital.

Director of Finance is responsible for providing detailed instructions on the collection, custody, investment, recording, safekeeping and disposal of patients' property that are detailed in point 5 (process) below in accordance with the advice provided by the local Counter Fraud advisor and local Security Advisor/LSMS.

Health and Safety Management Group will receive Security dash board report, which should include any alleged patient property losses i.e. incident relating to missing property reflective of Datix incident reporting.

Associate Directors of Nursing/Matrons /Sisters/Charge Nurses/Nursing Staff  Associate Directors of Nursing/Matrons /Sisters/Charge Nurses have overall responsibility to ensure that their teams are aware of this policy. Within all ward areas, reconciliation ward safe checks are to be completed daily. Written evidence of these checks must be retained for audit purposes.

Ward Managers are responsible for ensuring that ward staff are trained to implement this policy and will ensure that ward staff are made aware at the time of their appointment of their responsibilities and duties for the management and safekeeping of patient's property and adherence to the procedure. In addition, they are responsible for ensuring that patients and or their representatives are made aware of the procedures relating to patient property, that any cash deposits of over £200.00 will be banked within  hours, unless otherwise requested by the Ward Manager to hold until the patients discharge, depending on the amount.

Finally, it is the responsibility of the ward manager to investigate any issues relating to lost property through Trust incident reporting system in conjunction with EFM Head of Security and Car Parking/LSMS.
All nursing staff at all grades are responsible for ensuring that patient property and valuables are kept in the ward or security office safe with clear supporting documentation in the property book.

Staff should use interpretation service to explain the policy to patients that do not have English as a first language. For patients with a Learning Disability appropriate advice should be sought from the Learning Disabilities Nurse Specialist.

Clinical and Corporate Directors are responsible for ensuring that the staff within their Directorate are aware and comply fully with the policy. They are also responsible for ensuring that compliance to the policy is audited and the results of the audits are communicated to the Board.
Head of Security and Car Parking/LSMS will lead on security management work locally in accordance with national standards and report directly to the Senior Director of Estates and Facilities.

EFM Customer Services Cashier (General Office) are responsible for providing secure storage for inpatient's cash and or valuable property handed over to Trust for safe custody and performing related administrative functions, Also the safekeeping and disposal of unclaimed and lost property.

Bereavement Administration Service are responsible for releasing the property of deceased patients to the next of kin or authorised /nominated person and ensuring that they sign the appropriate paperwork. This service will also in certain cases assist with the search of alleged missing property should it be across several areas, but are not responsible for reimbursement of any lost property as accountability is with the ward/department.
Patient Advice and Liaison Office – provide information to patients on the Trust procedures for lost/mislaid property as required but do not deal with property issues.

Safeguarding Team - Where fraud is suspected or proven the Safeguarding Team will follow local protocol and work with all relevant personnel to safeguard the patient from further harm or exploitation.
Trust Patient property transfer / disclaimer form
When property is taken into custody for safe keeping, wards and departments must use the designated Trust patient property transfer/disclaimer form 343a (refer to Appendix 1).
It should also be used if patients retain valuable property in their own safe keeping at their own risk.
This form is Trust Finance Department ‘controlled stationery' and can only be obtained from Customer Services Cashiers (General Office). It is self-carbonating and comprised of 3 copies:
The top copy (white) must be given to the patient.
If the patient lacks capacity, the white copy must be given to the authorised or nominated person or placed in the patient's medical records.
In the case of a deceased patient, the white copy must be kept with the property and taken to the Bereavement Administration Office.
The second copy (yellow) is to be retained by the ward/department in a designated valuables form folder.
The final copy (blue) is for Customer Services (Cashiers Office/General Office) use. This must be signed along with the yellow ward copy by Customer Services (Cashiers Office/General Office).

When property is deposited at Customer services (Cashiers Office/General Office) or in the case of deceased patient taken to the Bereavement Administration Service with signed indemnity form for filing (Appendix 4).

The property must be listed, identifying quantity of items. Logging of patient property must include dentures, glasses and hearing aids as well as personal electronic devices, patient valuables, monies and cash.
Once completed the original property documentation should not be amended or altered in any way. This is required in order to maintain the integrity of the audit trail.
Any ‘spoiled' entries should be retained in the property folder, crossed through, signed and clearly marked “cancelled”.
Managing patient valuables and personal property

Money must be listed identifying specific amount in words and figures. Bank and credit cards /cheque books and bank books must also be identified. Small electrical items and personal electronic devices such as iPods, tablets and phones need to be listed. If money amounts to over £200, patients should be advised that it will be returned in the form of a BACS payment in the interests of safety and security.
Jewellery handed over for safekeeping must be listed with a description. Metal must be described as yellow or white and stones should be identified by their colour.

The valuables must be placed in a valuables envelope (ref no 812). The envelope must be sealed and either a member of nursing staff and the patient or two members of staff must sign across this seal. If necessary, the envelope can then be secured with sellotape placed over the two signatures.

During office hours, the valuables in their sealed envelope together with the 3-part patient property transfer / disclaimer form should be taken to Customer Services. They will check the valuables and sign the property transfer / disclaimer form. The top white copy of the patient's property transfer / disclaimer form is returned to the patient or placed in the patient clinical record.
During out of Office hours the valuables together with the property form should be placed in the night safe, which is located in the telephonist room. Customer

Services will collect the valuables on the next working day and place the valuables in the Customer Services safe. The white and yellow copies of patient property the white and yellow copies of patient property transfer/ disclaimer form will be signed
and returned to the ward. If the valuables belonged to a deceased person then they are passed on to the Bereavement Administration office for safe keeping.
Valuables returned to the patient on the ward must be documented by patient signature on Customer Services Return of Patient Property Form (343b) (Appendix

2). A member of staff or the patient can collect valuables held by Customer Services. Patients must be accompanied by a member of staff when collecting property from Customer Services, to confirm identity unless patient is self- managing, has wrist band ID and ward have telephoned in advance of patient's arrival at Customer Services. Customer Services staff may be able to return valuable property to the patient on the ward if they have the resources at the time of the request being made by the ward.

After discharge, patients collecting property from Customer Services Cashiers (General Office) must provide photo I.D with signature, to confirm their identity. If any other person is asked by the patient to collect their property on their behalf, then they must bring a signed letter from the patient giving the name and signature of the individual who is collecting the valuables.

If a patient does not have the capacity to write and sign a letter, then the nominated carer (residential Home/ Care Home representative) must provide photographic ID and a workplace letter confirming they are taking responsibility for the valuables.

When the patient is deceased, valuables will only be released to the next of kin or authorised/nominated person. The next of kin or authorised/nominated person must sign that they have received the valuables from the Bereavement Administration Service using the property indemnity form. (Appendix 4)
Valuables held by Customer Services can only be returned during normal working hours excluding Bank holidays and weekends.

Details of property/clothing removed or cut during treatment should be documented in the patient's records. If possible, consent should be obtained prior to cutting any garments, depending on patient condition.

Soiled patient property must be disposed of in accordance with MSEPO-21112 Waste Management Policy and Procedure. Patients or relatives must be informed of the reason for destruction and the details must be recorded in the Patient Clinical Record.

Cultural and religious valuables should be handled with dignity and respect. Where possible, patient's carers should be consulted about the culturally appropriate way to handle their valuables so no offence occurs. For advice when the patient or carer is unable to offer guidance please contact the Equality & Diversity Manager.
Staff should follow the flowchart on the next page (p11).
Checks of un-deposited property

When a patient is discharged, a member of staff from the discharging ward should go through their un-deposited property with them and check it against the list found on their patient Property Transfer/ disclaimer form (343a).

Once the property has been checked, the member of staff and the patient should sign the patient property disclaimer form. The form should have a discharge section with a statement for the patient to sign, acknowledging that the list provided on the form is a complete record of the patient's property and that the patient is still in possession of the items in the list at discharge.

data.text: Temporary custody of valuables, monies and cash

Temporary custody refers to retention of valuables, monies and cash/property, portable electronic devices for a period not exceeding  hours. Jewellery or valuable property is often placed in temporary custody whilst patients undergo treatment, surgery or overnight admission to A&E, AMS, AECS, DSU, SAU and Maternity.

Valuables placed in temporary custody must be recorded on Trust patient property transfer / disclaimer form 343a and placed in a valuables envelope (ref no 812). On the form, it should be identified as temporary custody and initialled by the member of staff completing the form. The envelope must be sealed and the seal signed by a staff member and the patient, or two members of staff.
The valuables must be placed in a secure locked cabinet /safe designated for such use on the ward (not the CD cupboard). The key must be held by the nurse in charge.
Two members of staff must check the contents of the secure locked cabinet/safe against the property book on admission, transfer or discharge from the ward.

Property must be returned to the patient within 24 hours. If the patient is unable to receive the property, the valuables must be placed in Customer Services or returned to the next of kin or authorised/nominated person with the patient's permission.

Valuables returned to the patient/ next of kin or authorised/nominated person must be documented and the patient / next of kin or authorised/nominated person must sign that they have received the valuables using the patient property transfer / disclaimer form 343a.
Transfer of patients

When a patient is transferred from another hospital, their property and valuables, monies and cash must be listed on their arrival using patient property transfer / disclaimer form 343a, and the procedure described in section 5 is followed.
On transfer to another hospital or between wards, all patient property and valuables must be recorded using form 343a.
Staff should follow the flow chart for patients who are being transferred

data.text: Details of patient property and valuables are recorded by the nurse arranging the patient's transfer and the nurse signs the form. It is the responsibility of the nurse to check to ensure that no valuables are being held in Customer Services.
The record and property are passed to the receiving ward, when the patient is transferred. The receiving nurse must sign the record of valuables and property form.
Property of deceased patients
Property of deceased patients must be placed in designated property bags after it has been listed on Trust patient property transfer / disclaimer form 343a.

The patient's name and receipt number must be written on a luggage label and attached to each property bag. The bag must be placed in a lockable cabinet or room within the ward and taken to the Bereavement Administration Service during opening hours, or as soon as possible the next working day.

All property of deceased patients including valuables is taken to the Bereavement Administration Service Office during normal working hours. Only property placed in the correct property bag will be accepted by Bereavement Administration Service
Valuables will be stored by the Bereavement Administration Service in their safe.
Deceased patient's property including valuables being held in safe custody in Customer Services will be transferred to the Bereavement Administration Service

Patient's next of kin or authorised/nominated person must be advised to telephone the Bereavement Administration Service on Weekdays after 10.00am to discuss the availability of the patient's death certificate and arrange for collection of property.

Staff in the Bereavement Administration Service will transfer property of deceased patients to the Bereavement Suite on the day of the death registration appointment. The property will be released to the next of kin as stated on the patient look up system or authorised/nominated person.

When property and valuables are given to relatives of deceased patients at ward level, it is essential to check that the claimant is entitled to the property, e.g. Next of Kin or authorised/nominated person before handing over any property/valuables.

If, for any reason you are concerned about the identity of the relative do not release property, monies, cash or valuables. For advice in hours, contact the Matron; out of hours contact the clinical site co-ordinator.

Valuables returned to the next of kin or authorised/nominated person must be documented and the next of kin or authorised/nominated person must sign that they have received the valuables using the patient property form 343a. A copy must be retained.

Soiled patient property must be appropriately disposed of in accordance with MSEPO-21112 Waste Management Policy; Pockets must be checked to ensure that valuables are not present. Property/clothing removed or cut during treatment should be documented in the patient's records. Patient's relatives must be informed of the reason for destruction.

When property is returned to the Next of Kin or authorised patient representative by the Bereavement Suite the next of kin or authorised/nominated person will be asked to sign the Bereavement Department patient property Indemnity form (Appendix 4). The signed form is returned to the Bereavement Administration Service for filing.

Unclaimed property – if deceased patient's valuables remain unclaimed after reasonable attempts to inform the next of kin to collect, they will be stored with Bereavement Administration Service for a period of 12 months after which time they will become the property of the Trust Finance Department and disposed of in accordance with standing financial instructions.
If the deceased has no monies or property in their Estate and no next of kin, the Trust cannot recoup the cost of arranging the funeral.

When the Bereavement Administration services have confirmed that there are monies in the estate of a deceased person who has no next of kin and is having a hospital funeral, the Trust must seek to recoup the funeral and administration costs (or as much as possible) The costs are then repaid into the Trust's funeral fund account.

The Trust may also be holding patient's monies that were taken into safe keeping by the Trust when the patient was admitted to hospital. The Trust is legally entitled to use these monies to cover the funeral and administration costs and the Bereavement Administration Service will arrange this.

If the patient has no will and their monies and equity are over and above £500 once the funeral costs and administration fee has been paid, the Bereavement Administration Service pass on all the details to the Treasury Solicitor.

Where property of a deceased patient is of a total value in excess of £5,000 (or such other amount as may be prescribed by any amendment to the Administration of Estates, Small Payments Act 1965), the production of Probate or Letters of Administration shall be required before any of the property is released. Where the total value of property is £5,000 or less, forms of indemnity shall be obtained.
The role of customer services
Staff in Customer Services fulfil a role in both receiving and releasing patient's property comprising valuables and clothing and follow agreed procedures.
Unclaimed or Lost Property should be taken to the Customer Services, and have the details entered in lost and found property register.

At any time during a stay as an in-patient, or on discharge, patients may request the return of their property/valuables; however, property can only be released during normal working hours (i.e. it cannot be released on Saturday, Sunday, or Bank Holidays). Patients being discharged over weekends/BH must have their property/valuables collected on the previous Friday or after discharge.
Releasing of property from customer services
The patient or their representative must take the yellow copy of Patient property transfer / disclaimer form 343a to General Office.

The patient or their representative must sign the Customer Services return of patient property form (343b) (refer to Appendix 2) for any property released to them. The patient must be accompanied by a member of staff to confirm identity unless patient is self-managing has wrist band ID and ward have telephoned in advance of patient's arrival at Customer Services.
After discharge, patients collecting property from Customer Services must provide photo I.D with signature, to confirm their identity.
Up to £200 in cash can be released from petty cash. For any amount above £200 a BACS payment will be made to patient's bank account.

In the event that a patient insists on full cash reimbursement, the patient must sign an indemnity form and the cashier must seek permission from Financial Services and complete Customer Service Reimbursement of Patient cash over £200 Form (343 c) (Appendix 3) to release the money and the Trust must have a reasonable amount of time to locate the necessary sum of money.

Property should only be released to someone other than the patient if a letter of authorisation from the patient is produced. If an unconscious patient is being transferred to another hospital, the nurse escorting the patient will sign for the patient's property and be responsible for the property until it is handed in for safe keeping at the hospital the patient is being transferred to. Any property belonging to an unconscious patient within the NHS organisation automatically becomes a Bailee of the property and will have the same duty in relation to it as in the case of voluntary bailment.
Patient valuables and property reported as missing
When patient property/valuables are reported as missing, a search of the relevant areas must be initiated by ward/department and actions taken as follows:
Check the patient's locker and bed area.
For patient valuables check the ward safe or if the property has gone to Customer Services
Check patients' property transfer/disclaimer form 343 a)
Check whether the disclaimer had been discussed and signed.
If the property/valuables cannot be located a Datix incident form must be completed, and an investigation initiated by the Ward/Dept Manager.
Police need to be involved if there is a possibility that the property has been stolen.
In this instance the Clinical Site Co-ordinator /Head Nurse, LSMS and the Safeguarding team must be involved and the incident added to Datix as a theft.
Inform Patient/relative that the item has been lost
If process has been followed and disclaimer signed, apologise for the loss. Notify that the trust is not responsible as disclaimer signed.
Provide the patient /relative with a copy of the disclaimer and any property list.
If the disclaimer was not signed, the ward is responsible.
If responsible arrange for Urgent special payment. An invoice must be received
from the person concerned and processed by Finance.
Consider Adult Safeguarding referral for financial abuse if the patient is a vulnerable adult.
Disposal of unclaimed property
All soiled clothing should be destroyed as set out in the MSEPO-21112 Waste management policy and procedure.
All clothing will be disposed of after  days in the appropriate waste stream.
All valuables will be held for a period of one year.

Items held for a period of 12 months that have not been claimed despite reasonable attempts to contact the individual or relatives will be disposed of in accordance with Trust standing financial instructions.
All electrical items, such as ipads, mobile phones and laptops will be listed and handed to IT to be securely destroyed using the same process as Trust PC equipment.
All clothing to be held within the ward until the  period and no clothing will be taken in at Customer Services.
Return of deposited property

When a patient is discharged from the Trust, any property they have handed in for safekeeping should be returned to them as soon as is practicable, following the procedure below. If the patient is incapacitated, it will be returned to their representative. Other than in this case, staff should not hand over property to anyone other than the patient without the patient's written consent.

Where property has been deposited in a central storage facility, the contents of the property envelope(s) or Bag(s) should be checked against the list in the property folder. This should be done in the presence of the member of staff collecting the property, who should sign for receipt. If any cash has been deposited Customer Services should obtain a separate signature for its return on Customer Services Return of Patient Property Form (343b) (Appendix 2).

Once the property has been returned to the ward or unit staff should ask the patient for their copy of the patient property transfer/disclaimer form(343a). Property should then be checked against this form and the patient asked to sign that property/valuables have been returned in good order.

data.text: Patients lacking capacity to make a decision about their property

Anyone who works with or cares for an adult who lacks capacity must comply with the Mental Capacity Act (MCA 2005). Staff at the individual sites must abide by the policy for the MSEPO-21103 Application of the Mental Capacity Act of 2005 Policy.
This applies no matter what type of decisions is involved, so decisions about patients' property are also covered by it.

Appropriate records of assessments of capacity and best-interests decisions should be made and stored. Records made in relation to the management of patient's property will help staff to show that they have acted in compliance with the MCA by providing evidences of the action taken.

The MCA provides a checklist which will contribute to protection from liability for carrying out certain actions in connection with the care and treatment of people who lack capacity to consent, provided that the person carrying out the actions:
Has observed the principles of the MCA;
Has carried out an assessment of capacity and reasonably believes that the person lacks capacity in relations to the matter in question
Reasonably believes the action taken is in the best interests of the patient.

Appropriate records of assessments of capacity and best-interest decisions should be made and stored. Records made in relation to the management of patient's property will help staff to show that they have acted in compliance with the MCA by providing evidences of the action taken.

It is important to note that the protection from liability does not extend to cases of Negligence. This means that if a member of staff makes a decision regarding a patients' property in line with the requirements of the MCA but then is negligent in handling the property they (and the NHS organisation) may be liable for any loss or damage that occurs.

Where staff have a reasonable belief that a patient lacks the capacity to make a particular decision about their property (e.g. handing certain items to the NHS health body for safekeeping), staff should consider whether everything has been done to help and support the patient to make the decision. They should also consider if the decision needs to be made without delay, and if not, whether it is possible to wait until the person has the capacity to make the decision for him or herself. For example, if the patient's lack of capacity is due to medication they are taking and is likely to last only a short time, it may be appropriate to wait until they regain capacity.

If everything has been done to support the patient to make the decision and it is not possible to wait until the patient may regain capacity, then staff should make an assessment of the patient's capacity in relation to the decision. If the patient has been assessed as lacking capacity to make the decision, then any action taken or decision made must be in their best interests. Staff should refer to the MCA Code of Practice for details on how to make assessments of capacity and take best-interests decisions, and on whether and how records should be made.

Staff should bear in mind that if a patient lacks capacity to make a certain decision on one occasion, that does not mean that they lack capacity to make another decision on the same or a different matter, or that they will lack capacity to make that decision in the future. For example, if a patient lacks capacity to make a decision about a withdrawal from their savings account, this does not mean they lack capacity to decide whether to keep a certain item of property by their bedside

The most common action staff may consider taking in relation to a patient's property when the patient lacks capacity to make a decision with regard to it is taking the property and placing it into safe custody, thus meeting the Trusts obligations as an involuntary Bailee of the property. Before doing so, staff should consider whether there is anyone with authority to make decisions on behalf of the patient, either a holder of a ‘property and affairs' Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA) or a deputy appointed by the Court of Protection. In practice the attorney or deputy will often be a relative or friend of the patient.

If an attorney or deputy is available, they must be consulted on what to do with the patient's property. They should be informed that the Trust will not accept liability for the patient's property unless it is handed over to the Trust for safekeeping. They should be encouraged to remove from the premises any property (especially
valuables) that the patient does not need, or otherwise to hand it over for safekeeping.

In cases where an attorney or deputy is not immediately available, staff may decide to take part or all of the patient's property into safe custody, if this is in the best interests of the patient. An attorney or deputy will however have to be involved in later decisions about the property. More details on attorneys and deputies, and on how staff should involve them in decisions, are provided in the MCA Code of Practice.

Staff should bear in mind that even where a patient is assessed as lacking capacity to make a decision, they should be involved as fully as possible in the decision. For example, when deciding which of a patient's belongings to remove from their bedside, every effort should be made to consider their wishes and feelings in this regard.
The procedure for taking into safe custody the property of a patient who lacks capacity to decide is much the same as for deposited property generally (see section 5 main process).

Where the patient is not attended by an attorney or deputy, two members of staff will need to place their signatures on the Property Transfer Form (343) the property will then be placed into safekeeping until the patient regains capacity to decide what should be done with it, or until the property can be given to the attorney or deputy. Where items are handed over for safekeeping by the attorney or representative, their signature is required on the Valuables form 343 wherever it is required for the patient.

Where a patient is discharged and lacks capacity to make a decision about their property, any deposited property should be given to their attorney or representative, obtaining their signature on the appropriate documentation.
Patients who decide not to hand over property for safekeeping but
choose to retain it with them on the premises.

Staff will need to inform the patient that not handing over any valuable belongings and retaining them on the hospital premises carries a higher risk of loss of or damage to the property, and that it intends to limit its liability if loss or damage occurred.

Staff will need to ask the patient to sign a patients' property transfer/disclaimer (form 343a (Appendix 1). The disclaimer proves that the patient is happy they have been advised to either have their valuables taken home or hand them in for safe keeping. The disclaimer also asks the patient to sign that they are solely responsible for their valuables whilst they choose to hold on to them during their stay in hospital.

Staff will have to ensure this form is signed by the patient and two members of staff who witness the form being completed. This form would only be appropriate if a patient has the capacity to make decisions for them.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the EFM Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Policy guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the EFM Governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 3: Customer service reimbursement of patient cash (over £200) form (343 c)
Cashier (General Office) Reimbursement of Patient Cash
The Trust has arrangements in place for the custody of patients' valuables and cash handed over for safe keeping during their stay as an in-patient.

With regard to safe custody of cash, one of the conditions in the interest of patient personal security is that if you are an inpatient, amounts over £200 are reimbursed on discharge by a BACS payment being sent from our Finance Department.

If for any reason you require a full cash reimbursement, please complete the request form below and approval should always be sort from the Director of Finance (Site Specific) or the Chief Financial Officer. Please note that the Trust can take no responsibility for the safe custody of this cash once it is returned to you by. This on-site facility is only available Monday to Friday 9.30am to 4.30pm excluding bank holidays.
